pr_title: [BEAM-9116] Limit the number of past invocations stored in JobService

timeline.message:
[BEAM-9116] Limit the number of past invocations stored in JobService

The InMemoryJobService stores an unbounded number of past job invocations. When
this job server is long-running this can cause memory issues, as seen with our
test setup for running Python tests.

This limits the number of past job invocations via a flag in the job server with
a sensible default.

timeline.bodyText: This variable name should be prefixed with DEFAULT to distinguish it from maxInvocationHistory.
timeline.author: ibzib

timeline.bodyText: The option name should match the variable name.
timeline.author: ibzib

replies.bodyText:
This name is user-facing and does not have to reflect the internal design decisions. The usage description could be improved:

"The maximum number of completed jobs to keep."
replies.author: mxm

timeline.author: ibzib

replies.bodyText: True. I think I was feeling funny when I wrote this.
replies.author: mxm

timeline.bodyText: There are really only two cases to test, maxRunningJobs <= maxInvocationHistory and maxRunningJobs > maxInvocationHistory. The randomness is unnecessary IMO.
timeline.author: ibzib

timeline.bodyText: I'd prefer if this whole block was declarative, rather than using iteration and branching.
timeline.author: ibzib

replies.bodyText: Please enlighten me how to do that :)
replies.author: mxm

replies.bodyText:
I was thinking we could have a small number of jobs, then finish them and check them one by one. Something like this (pseudocode):
job[0].finish()
assert(jobInfoCount == 4)
job[1].finish()
assert(jobInfoCount == 3)
...

Doing this instead of a for loop makes the test substantially easier to read. Errors also become easier to locate, because each assertion will be on its own line. If it's too verbose, we can probably factor out redundant/irrelevant code into helper methods. WDYT?
replies.author: ibzib

replies.bodyText: Sounds reasonable. Please have a look at the updated PR.
replies.author: mxm
